citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility has failed to follow the direction of the Attending Veterinarian (AV) regarding the care of animals.
***A 2-year-old male giraffe is emaciated. The AV sent the facility Director written instructions on August 24, 2023 which
are not being followed. 1) The AV’s instructions state “Please look into having the alfalfa hay tested for nutritional value.”
At the time of the inspection (September 6, 2023) the facility had not identified or tried to identify a means to have
nutritional testing done on the alfalfa hay fed to the giraffe. 2) The AV instructed the facility to offer browse throughout the
day, especially in the “early in the morning and late in the afternoon”. Facility staff, including the primary giraffe keeper,
indicated that feeding is not performed before 10AM. 3) The AV instructed the facility to contact their secondary
veterinarian and have her “draw blood for CBC, Chemistry”. The facility director stated that they have not contacted the
secondary veterinarian to schedule a blood draw because the giraffe is not yet trained for voluntary blood draws, and that
this training may take an indeterminant amount of time. 4) The AV requested a daily report on the giraffe to include
detailed information on food consumption, activity, fecal output, rumination, and behavior. Review of the daily keeper
documentation sent to the AV only includes observations related to diet, most or all of the other information is not
documented.
***A 2-year-old brown female alpaca (“Babette”) has an eye issue. On August 31, 2023 the AV wrote in this animal’s
record that it should be treated with an anti-inflammatory eye medication twice a day and artificial tears three times per
day. When asked what type of eye medication the animal is receiving, the facility Director stated that eye antibiotics are
given twice a day. The other eye medications are not being administered. Medical records contain no entries for eye
medications administered.
It is important to follow the AV’s instructions regarding the care and treatment of animals. Failure to follow the AV’s
instructions may result in animals suffering from poor or inadequate care, worsening of animals’ health conditions, or even
animal death.
Correct by September 8, 2023 at 12:00PM Central time by following the AV’s instructions, and by ensuring that the AV
has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other
aspects of animal care and use.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The facility currently has animals (2 wallaby, 2 armadillos, 2 owls, and 1 tenrec) on exhibit at offsite locations (where the
animals are staying overnight) but has not submitted an itinerary to USDA. Itinerary submission is important so that
animals can be inspected at offsite locations, to ensure animal welfare and compliance with the Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by September 8, 2023 by submitting a written itinerary for all future overnight travel to USDA APHIS Animal Care
at least 48 hours before departure.

An outdoor enclosure housing two adult Asian Small Clawed otters contains an empty pool that is 6-feet deep. The sides
of the pool are smooth with no steps or ramps that would allow an animal to climb out of the empty pool. The Assistant
Director stated that the pool was drained for repairs. The otters could easily fall into the pool and become injured, and
they would be unable to get out. Animals may become injured when housed in enclosures that contain hazards such as
empty pools that cannot be climbed out of. Correct by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound and
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. Some previously identified non-
complaint items remain uncorrected, but correction time remains on those items.

Two of the Rainbow Lorikeet’s are being temporarily housed in a small cage in a building. Running along the side and
across the top of the lori’s cage was an extension cord. The lori’s could easily bite the cord and electrocute themselves.
The primary enclosure must protect the birds from injury. Correct by September 8, 2023, by removing the extension cord
from the top and side of the lori cage
This inspection was conducted with the Director and staff, and exit interview was conducted with the owner and the
director.
Additional Inspectors:
CYNTHIA DIGESUALDO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility has failed to follow the direction of the Attending Veterinarian (AV) regarding the care of animals. 
***A 2-year-old male giraffe is emaciated. The AV sent the facility Director written instructions on August 24, 2023 which 
are not being followed. 1) The AV’s instructions state “Please look into having the alfalfa hay tested for nutritional value.” 
At the time of the inspection (September 6, 2023) the facility had not identified or tried to identify a means to have 
nutritional testing done on the alfalfa hay fed to the giraffe. 2) The AV instructed the facility to offer browse throughout the 
day, especially in the “early in the morning and late in the afternoon”. Facility staff, including the primary giraffe keeper, 
indicated that feeding is not performed before 10AM. 3) The AV instructed the facility to contact their secondary 
veterinarian and have her “draw blood for CBC, Chemistry”. The facility director stated that they have not contacted the 
secondary veterinarian to schedule a blood draw because the giraffe is not yet trained for voluntary blood draws, and that 
this training may take an indeterminant amount of time. 4) The AV requested a daily report on the giraffe to include 
detailed information on food consumption, activity, fecal output, rumination, and behavior. Review of the daily keeper 
documentation sent to the AV only includes observations related to diet, most or all of the other information is not 
documented.  
***A 2-year-old brown female alpaca (“Babette”) has an eye issue. On August 31, 2023 the AV wrote in this animal’s

day. When asked what type of eye medication the animal is receiving, the facility Director stated that eye antibiotics are 
given twice a day. The other eye medications are not being administered. Medical records contain no entries for eye 
medications administered.  
It is important to follow the AV’s instructions regarding the care and treatment of animals. Failure to follow the AV’s

Correct by September 8, 2023 at 12:00PM Central time by following the AV’s instructions, and by ensuring that the AV 
has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other 
aspects of animal care and use. 
2.126(c) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.

The facility currently has animals (2 wallaby, 2 armadillos, 2 owls, and 1 tenrec) on exhibit at offsite locations (where the 
animals are staying overnight) but has not submitted an itinerary to USDA. Itinerary submission is important so that 
animals can be inspected at offsite locations, to ensure animal welfare and compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. 
Correct by September 8, 2023 by submitting a written itinerary for all future overnight travel to USDA APHIS Animal Care 
at least 48 hours before departure. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
An outdoor enclosure housing two adult Asian Small Clawed otters contains an empty pool that is 6-feet deep. The sides 
of the pool are smooth with no steps or ramps that would allow an animal to climb out of the empty pool. The Assistant 
Director stated that the pool was drained for repairs. The otters could easily fall into the pool and become injured, and 
they would be unable to get out. Animals may become injured when housed in enclosures that contain hazards such as 
empty pools that cannot be climbed out of. Correct by ensuring that all animal enclosures are structurally sound and 
maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. Some previously identified non-
complaint items remain uncorrected, but correction time remains on those items. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two of the Rainbow Lorikeet’s are being temporarily housed in a small cage in a building. Running along the side and 
across the top of the lori’s cage was an extension cord. The lori’s could easily bite the cord and electrocute themselves. 
The primary enclosure must protect the birds from injury. Correct by September 8, 2023, by removing the extension cord 
from the top and side of the lori cage 
 
This inspection was conducted with the Director and staff, and exit interview was conducted with the owner and the 
director. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CYNTHIA DIGESUALDO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
